formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0287>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The equations assert two identification constraints. First, for every pair (x, y), the product p(x, y) times the candidate joint quantity \cP(x, y) equals the value produced by a deterministic procedure \Phi applied to the censored distribution \cC_\cD and evaluated at (x, y). Second, the X-marginal of \cP must equal the observed covariate marginal \cD_X, reflecting that covariates are uncensored. Together, these conditions restrict \cP to those joint distributions consistent with the censored data via \Phi while preserving the observed covariate distribution.

notations.\\Phi(\\cC_\\cD)(x,y): Output of the deterministic procedure \Phi applied to the censored distribution \cC_\cD, evaluated at (x, y)
notations.\\cC_\\cD: Censored distribution associated with \cD (provided as input)
notations.\\cP_X(x): Marginal distribution of covariates X under \cP evaluated at x
notations.\\cD_X(x): Marginal distribution of covariates X under \cD evaluated at x

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0356>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This piecewise definition gives the density of the observed (censored) data triple (X, y, t) induced by an observational study. If t=1, it factors as the joint density of (X, Y(1)) times the probability of receiving treatment given X and Y(1); if t=0, it uses the joint density of (X, Y(0)) and the probability of not receiving treatment given X and Y(0). It encodes the observed-data law where only the relevant potential outcome is revealed depending on treatment assignment.

notations.\\cC_{\\cD^{(i)}}(x,y,t): Density of the observed/censored data (X, y, t) evaluated at (x, y, t) under the i-th observational study
notations.\\cD^{(i)}: The i-th observational study distribution constructed in the argument
notations.\\cD_{X,Y(1)}^{(i)}(x,y): Joint density of (X, Y(1)) under the i-th observational study, evaluated at (x, y)
notations.\\Pr_{\\cD^{(i)}}[T{=}1\\mid X{=}x, Y(1): Conditional probability of receiving treatment given X = x and Y(1) = y under the i-th observational study
notations.\\cD_{X,Y(0)}^{(i)}(x,y): Joint density of (X, Y(0)) under the i-th observational study, evaluated at (x, y)
notations.\\Pr_{\\cD^{(i)}}[T{=}0\\mid X{=}x, Y(0): Conditional probability of not receiving treatment given X = x and Y(0) = y under the i-th observational study
notations.y: Observed outcome value (equals the treated potential outcome when t = 1 and the control potential outcome when t = 0)
notations.i: Index identifying which constructed observational study is used (e.g., 1 or 2)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0417>>
formulas.formula:
\begin{split}
                        \snorm{p\cP - p_0\cD_{X,Y(0)}}_1
                    &\coloneqq 
                    \iint \abs{p(x,y)\cP(x,y)-p_0(x,y)\cD_{X,Y(0)}(x,y)}\d x\d y
                     \leq \eps \,,\\
                    \snorm{q\cQ - p_1\cD_{X,Y(1)}}_1
                    &\coloneqq 
                    \iint \abs{p(x,y)\cP(x,y)-p_1(x,y)\cD_{X,Y(1)}(x,y)}\d x\d y
                     \leq \eps \,.
                    \end{split}
                    \yesnum\label{eq:techOverview:est:2}
formulas.high_level_explanation: These equations define the L1 (total variation) distance between certain product functions/densities and their targets, and require both distances to be at most a small tolerance epsilon. Each distance is written as a double integral over x and y of the absolute difference between the corresponding products. Operationally, this enforces that the learned/product pairs approximate the target products in total variation up to epsilon.

notations.\\eps: Sufficiently small tolerance parameter (as referenced by the context)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0497>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This condition imposes uniform bounds on two odds-type ratios formed from e(x) and the functions p_0(x,y) and p_1(x,y). Specifically, for every x in R^d, y in R, and t in the specified set, each ratio lies between 1/Λ and Λ. Intuitively, it restricts how far these odds can deviate from 1, acting as a sensitivity-style constraint while assuming overlap.

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0558>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression defines the class hyPunconf(c) of functions p from a covariate–outcome space to probabilities that satisfy two properties. First, p does not depend on the outcome argument (p(x, y1) = p(x, y2) for all y1, y2), encoding outcome-independence (unconfoundedness). Second, there exists a subset S of the covariate space with measure at least c such that p(x, y) > c for all x in S and all y, capturing a weak overlap requirement on a nontrivial region rather than everywhere.

notations.\\hyPunconf(c): Class of functions p satisfying outcome-independence and c-weak-overlap as specified
notations.S: Subset of the covariate space on which the overlap condition holds
notations.c: Overlap level parameter used both as a lower bound on p and as a minimum required measure of S

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0654>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This formula gives an order-level upper bound on the number of samples needed to estimate the ATE in Scenario II with confidence 1−δ. The sample size scales inversely with η·M(ε/2)^2 and depends on the complexity of the involved classes through the fat‑shattering dimension of H_P at scale η c σ M(ε/2) and the covering number of H_D at scale η c M(ε/2). The logarithmic terms capture dependence on confidence (δ) and on the metric entropies of the classes.

notations.\\mathrm{fat}_{\\eta c\\sigma M(\\nfrac{: Fat-shattering dimension of \hyP at scale \eta c \sigma M(\nfrac{\eps}{2})
notations.\\hyP: Concept class (hypothesis class) with finite fat-shattering dimension
notations.\\sigma: Smoothness parameter from the σ-smoothness assumption with respect to \mu
notations.N_{\\eta {c}M(\\nfrac{\\eps}{2})}(\\hyD): Covering number of \hyD at scale \eta c M(\nfrac{\eps}{2}) with respect to total variation distance
notations.\\hyD: Class of distributions with a finite total-variation covering number

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0706>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression defines the class \hyPunconf(c) of propensity score functions. Each function p maps (x, y) in R^d × R to [0,1] and must be independent of y (i.e., for fixed x, p does not vary with y). In addition, there must exist a subset S of the covariate space with volume at least c such that p(x, y) is uniformly greater than c for all y when x lies in S, ensuring a nontrivial lower bound on propensities over S.

notations.\\hyPunconf(c): Class of propensity score functions captured by this definition for parameter c
notations.S: A subset of \R^d satisfying \vol(S) \ge c and on which p(x,y) > c for all y

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0740>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This is a big-O upper bound on the sample size n needed by the estimation algorithm to succeed with high probability. The bound scales as C^2 divided by (c^2·ε)^4, multiplied by a complexity term that combines the fat-shattering dimension of the hypothesis class hyP at a scale proportional to η·σ·c^3·ε/C and a logarithmic term involving the covering number of the distribution class hyD and the confidence parameter δ. The capacity measures reflect how rich the classes hyP and hyD are, and the big-O hides universal constants.

notations.\\eps: Target accuracy tolerance of the estimator
notations.\\sigma: Smoothness parameter of the distributions with respect to \mu
notations.\\eta: Universal constant appearing in the bound
notations.\\hyP: Concept (hypothesis) class with finite fat-shattering dimension
notations.\\hyD: Class of distributions with a finite total-variation covering number
notations.\\mathrm{fat}_{\\eta\\sigma c^3\\eps/C}(: Fat-shattering dimension of \hyP at scale \eta\sigma c^3\eps/C
notations.N_{\\eta c^3\\eps/C}(\\hyD): Covering number of \hyD (with respect to total variation distance) at radius \eta c^3\eps/C

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0789>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This expression gives a big-O upper bound on the sample size n required by the RD-design estimator. The required n scales like C^2/(σ c ε)^2 multiplied by a complexity term combining the fat-shattering dimension of the class \hyP at scale O(σ c ε/C) and the covering number of the class \hyD at scale O(ε c/C), together with logarithmic factors. It highlights how the geometric/conditioning constant C and the parameters σ, c, ε interact with the statistical complexities of \hyP and \hyD.

notations.C: Constant that depends on the geometry of K; scales linearly with the diameter of K and with a function of the aspect ratio (as stated in the context)
notations.c: Parameter associated with the RD design (appears in the c-RD-design)
notations.\\mathrm{fat}_{O(\\sigma c\\eps/C)}(\\hy: Fat-shattering dimension of the class \hyP at scale O(\sigma c\eps / C)
notations.N_{O(\\eps c/C)}(\\hyD): Covering number of the class \hyD at scale O(\eps c / C)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0797>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: These three conditions relate two distributions over (X, Y). First, the expectation of Y under distribution P differs from that under Q. Second, P and Q share the same marginal distribution over X. Third, there exist pointwise weights p and q such that p(x, y) times P’s joint probability (mass/density) equals q(x, y) times Q’s joint probability for every x in the support of P’s X-marginal and all real y; equivalently, the two joint laws can be matched by reweighting. In the proof, these jointly lead to a contradiction with the first condition, supporting an identifiability claim.

notations.\\cP(x,y): Joint probability (mass or density) of (x, y) under \cP
notations.\\cQ(x,y): Joint probability (mass or density) of (x, y) under \cQ

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0829>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: These three conditions posit two distributions P and Q over (X, Y) such that they share the same marginal distribution for X and satisfy a c-overlap (bounded likelihood-ratio) condition, yet they yield different expectations of the outcome y. The second line enforces equality of the X-marginals, while the third line bounds the pointwise likelihood ratio P(x, y)/Q(x, y) within an interval determined by c over the relevant support. Together, these constraints are used to argue (e.g., by construction) that identification can fail despite overlap, since E_P[y] differs from E_Q[y].

notations.\\cP: A distribution over the joint variables (X, Y)
notations.\\cQ: A distribution over the joint variables (X, Y)
notations.x: A value of the covariate X
notations.y: A value of the outcome variable Y
notations.\\supp(\\cP_X): Support of the marginal distribution of X under \cP
notations.\\cP(x,y): Joint probability mass or density of (X, Y) under \cP at the point (x, y)
notations.\\cQ(x,y): Joint probability mass or density of (X, Y) under \cQ at the point (x, y)
notations.\\frac{\\cP(x,y)}{\\cQ(x,y)}: Pointwise likelihood ratio between \cP and \cQ at (x, y)
notations.c: Overlap constant from the c-overlap condition (exact range NOT MENTIONED)
notations.\\frac{c}{1-c}: Lower bound of the allowable likelihood-ratio interval implied by the c-overlap condition
notations.\\frac{1-c}{c}: Upper bound of the allowable likelihood-ratio interval implied by the c-overlap condition

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0855>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: These relations state a contrast between two distributions: the expected value of Y under \cP differs from that under \cQ, yet their marginals over X are identical. Additionally, for every x in the support of the X-marginal of \cP and every real y, the weighted joint masses/densities of \cP and \cQ match pointwise via functions p and q. Together, this characterizes a situation where the covariate distributions agree but the outcome means differ while a reweighting equalizes the joint distributions.

notations.\\cP(x,y): Joint probability mass/density of (X,Y) under \cP evaluated at (x,y)
notations.\\cQ(x,y): Joint probability mass/density of (X,Y) under \cQ evaluated at (x,y)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0932>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This set of inequalities provides a standard two-step accuracy argument for an estimator of the target parameter. First, the expected difference between the practical estimator and an oracle estimator is at most epsilon/2; second, the oracle estimator is unbiased for the target (its expectation equals tau); third, the practical estimator concentrates within epsilon/2 of the oracle mean with probability at least 1 - delta. Together (via the triangle inequality), these imply the estimator is epsilon-close to tau with high probability.

notations.\\Ex: Expectation with respect to the data-generating distribution
notations.\\Pr: Probability with respect to the data-generating distribution
notations.\\wh{\\tau}: Constructed estimator of the target parameter using estimated nuisance quantities
notations.\\bar{\\tau}: Oracle estimator defined using the true propensity score (or true nuisance quantities)
notations.\\delta: Failure probability (so 1 - delta is the confidence level)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_0959>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The expression defines a partition of the set S into two subsets based on a likelihood-ratio threshold. Specifically, S_L collects points (x, y) where the ratio of the two densities is below c/(2(1−c)), and S_R collects points where the ratio exceeds 2(1−c)/c. These reciprocal thresholds separate regions where one density is much smaller or much larger than the other, relative to the overlap constant c. This partition is used to derive bounds in the proof under the c-overlap condition.

notations.S_L: Subset of S where the likelihood ratio \frac{\cD_{X,Y(1)}(x,y)}{\cP(x,y)} is below \frac{c}{2(1-c)}
notations.S_R: Subset of S where the likelihood ratio \frac{\cD_{X,Y(1)}(x,y)}{\cP(x,y)} exceeds \frac{2(1-c)}{c}
notations.S: Set specified in the overlap condition (cond:Over:estimation)
notations.\\frac{\\cD_{X,Y(1)}(x,y)}{\\cP(x,y)}: Likelihood ratio between the two densities at (x, y)
notations.c: Overlap constant from the c-overlap condition

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1027>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality bounds from below the conditional probability (under x drawn from D_X) that the true propensity score e(x) is at least c − 2√ε given that x lies in the constructed set Ŝ_1. The bound is obtained by subtracting the mass of a bad set B from the mass of Ŝ_1 and normalizing by the mass of Ŝ_1, then using lower/upper bounds on these masses. The final expression shows this probability is at least 1 − √ε/(c − √ε), i.e., close to 1 when ε is small relative to c.

notations.e(x): Propensity score evaluated at covariate x
notations.\\cD_X: Distribution (measure) over the covariate space X used to sample x
notations.\\wh{S}_1: Constructed subset of the feature space used in the algorithm (known set used for truncation/estimation)
notations.B: Bad set defined in the proof where the desired property may fail

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1035>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The inequality bounds, over the subset \wh{S^T}_1 of the x-domain, the integrated absolute difference between a fitted density P' and a plug-in estimator formed by the product of two estimated functions divided by an estimated propensity score. It is an L1-type accuracy guarantee on the truncated region, showing that this plug-in estimator is close to some candidate density with error on the order of sqrt(eps)/c. As the estimation error parameter eps decreases and c is not too small, the discrepancy shrinks at rate proportional to sqrt(eps)/c.

notations.\\cP'(x,y): A candidate distribution/density from the hypothesis class chosen in step (ii) of the algorithm; the target density used for approximation on the specified set
notations.\\wh{p}(x,y): Estimated version of p(x,y) obtained from samples; the excerpt does not specify what p represents
notations.\\wh{\\cP}(x,y): Estimated version of the true density \cP(x,y) obtained from samples

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1046>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality applies the triangle inequality to upper bound the L1 distance (over x in \wh{S}_1) between the ratio (\wh{p}\,\wh{\cP})/\wh{e} and the target density \cP. It splits the error into two parts: (i) the discrepancy between the estimated product \wh{p}\,\wh{\cP} and the target product p\,\cP, scaled by 1/\wh{e}(x); and (ii) the residual arising from replacing \cP by (p\,\cP)/\wh{e}(x). This decomposition enables separate control of the numerator estimation error and the effect of the denominator.

notations.\\wh{p}(x,y): Estimated function paired with \wh{\cP} so that their product approximates p(x,y)\,\cP(x,y)
notations.\\wh{e}(x): Estimated version of the function e(x)
notations.\\cP(x,y): True density over (x,y) from the distribution class considered

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1050>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: The inequality decomposes the L1 distance (over x and y) between the reweighted quantity p(x,y)·\cP(x,y)/\hat e(x) and the target density \cP(x,y) across the set \hat S_1 into contributions from two regions: the complement of a bad set B and the bad set itself. It simply splits the integral over \hat S_1 into the sum of integrals over \hat S_1 \ B and \hat S_1 ∩ B, allowing separate bounds on each part.

notations.\\wh{S}_1: Known subset of the x-domain (mentioned as known in the context)
notations.B: Bad subset of the x-domain referenced in eq:est:scenario3:badSet
notations.{\\cP}(x,y): Joint density of the distribution \cP over (x,y) (a member of the class \hyD)

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1056>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality bounds, over the "good" region x ∈ \wh{S}_1 \setminus B, the L1 deviation between the reweighted quantity p(x,y)\cP(x,y)/\wh{e}(x) and the target density \cP(x,y). On that region, the deviation is controlled by a factor of \sqrt{\eps} times the mass of \cP on the same region. The rightmost inequality asserts a lower bound on that mass term, yielding an overall bound proportional to \sqrt{\eps}. This is used to show that the reweighting error is small outside the bad set B.

formulas.label: <<FORMULA_1061>>
formulas.high_level_explanation: This inequality bounds the L1 deviation, over the subset where x lies in the intersection \wh S_1 ∩ B, between the reweighted quantity p(x,y)·\cP(x,y)/\wh e(x) and the target density \cP(x,y). The first bound shows the integral is at most ((1/(c − √ε)) − 1) times the \cP-mass of \wh S_1 ∩ B, and the second uses a small-mass bound for that set to conclude an O(√ε/(c − √ε)) contribution. Intuitively, the error coming from the "bad" region is controlled both by a denominator lower bound and by the fact that the bad set has small probability under \cP.

notations.\\cP: Target distribution/density; \cP(x,y) denotes its density and \cP(A) the mass of a set A
